data.title: PETER STEELE Death: A Look Back At The TYPE O NEGATIVE Legend
data.meta_description: Peter Steele Death: TYPE O NEGATIVE's Gothic Metal Luminary's final days and the lasting impact he left behind.
data.text:
Peter Steele Death: A Gothic Metal Luminary’s final days

Peter Steele, the towering figurehead of TYPE O NEGATIVE, tragically passed away on April 14, 2010, at the age of 48. His death sent shockwaves through the heavy metal community, leaving an irreplaceable void in the world of gothic metal.

Beyond his distinctive baritone voice and imposing stage presence, Steele was a complex individual whose life and music resonated with a multitude of fans. To this very day people are still discovering the music and the mythos that was the iconic Peter Steele and the music of TYPE O NEGATIVE.

From CARNIVORE to TYPE O NEGATIVE: A Musical Evolution

Before becoming the gothic metal icon synonymous with TYPE O NEGATIVE, Peter made his mark in the world of heavy metal with the band CARNIVORE. Formed in the early 1980s, CARNIVORE‘s music was a far cry from the atmospheric soundscapes that would define Steele‘s later work with “the drab four“. With a raw, aggressive style that blended elements of thrash metal and hardcore punk, CARNIVORE carved out a sizeable niche for themselves in the burgeoning underground metal scenes of Brooklyn and New York at the time.

Steele‘s powerful vocals and imposing stage presence were already evident in CARNIVORE, (Peter stood 6′ 7″ (201 cm) tall, giving him a menacing stage appearance), but it was with TYPE O NEGATIVE that his artistic vision truly blossomed.

Following the dissolution of CARNIVORE shortly after the release of their second album, 1987’s “Retaliation“, Peter Steele embarked on a new musical venture. Writhing in pain due to the breakup of his latest relationship, Peter took his bass and angst ridden lyrics and focused that energy on forming a new band initially known as REPULSION, which would later evolve into the iconic TYPE O NEGATIVE. According to the liner notes of the “Top Shelf Edition” of CARNIVORE‘s second album, much of the material that would eventually shape the sound of TYPE O‘s debut, “Slow, Deep and Hard,” originated from his earlier band.

TYPE O NEGATIVE‘s formation in 1989 marked a significant departure from the aggressive sound of Steele‘s former band. Along with guitarist Kenny Hickey, keyboardist/producer Josh Silver and drummer Sal Abruscato (later replaced by Johnny Kelly after the release of “Bloody Kisses“), the new band incorporated elements of doom, gothic rock, and heavy metal into their music, creating a unique and atmospheric sound that would define the gothic metal genre.

Steele‘s lyrics took on a darker, more introspective tone with TYPE O NEGATIVE. He delved into profound themes of love, loss, addiction, and mortality with a raw honesty that resonated deeply with listeners. Albums such as “Bloody Kisses“, “October Rust“, and “World Coming Down” propelled TYPE O to the forefront of the gothic metal scene, quickly solidifying their status as it’s influential pioneers.

The Shadow Side: Struggles with Addiction

Behind the imposing figure and the dark, poetic lyrics lay a man battling personal demons. Peter Steele was candid about his struggles with alcohol and drug abuse, which often fueled his creative output but also took a toll on his personal life. His lyrics served as a cathartic outlet, allowing him to confront his own vulnerabilities and share his experiences through his music.

Steele‘s openness about his struggles assisted greatly in destigmatizing mental health and addiction issues within the heavy metal community. His willingness to share his pain and overwhelming challenges created a sense of connection with fans who were going through similar situations in life. The music, if anything, could provide an outlet, or at least an escape from life’s complexities, albeit in a dark and gothic way.

A Complex and Troubled Soul

Peter was a multifaceted individual whose public persona as a gothic metal frontman masked a complex and often troubled soul. His lyrics served as a window into his inner world, revealing a man grappling with demons and searching for meaning.

Steele‘s upbringing in Brooklyn, New York, shaped his worldview and influenced his music. He often drew inspiration from the gritty reality of his surroundings, incorporating it into his songwriting.

The Impact of TYPE O NEGATIVE

TYPE O NEGATIVE‘s music transcended the boundaries of heavy metal, appealing to a wide range of listeners. The band’s ability to blend darkness and melody, coupled with Steele‘s distinctive, deep vocals, created a unique and enduring type of music that almost hypnotically pulls you in to a dark, candlelit chamber of sound, engulfing you in it’s beauty before pummeling you with an overly distorted, drop tuned attack.

Albums like “Bloody Kisses” and “October Rust” achieved mainstream success, introducing gothic metal to a broader audience and saw the band grow exponentially in popularity, particularly among women, who were another of Steele‘s well-known indulgences. Peter‘s songwriting prowess and the band’s innovative approach to music helped to redefine the genre and pave the way for future generations of artists.

In a candid interview before his passing, Peter Steele acknowledged the toll his prolonged battles with alcohol and cocaine had taken on his body. He stated, “I developed heart problems, I developed liver problems, I never had a stroke, I never had a heart attack and as Mark Twain put it, ‘Rumors of my death have been highly exaggerated.'”

Peter Steele Death

Tragically, Peter Steele died on April 14, 2010, at the age of 48. The official cause of death was sepsis brought on by diverticulitis, though heart failure was initially reported. Despite his health challenges, Steele was actively working on new music prior to his untimely passing.

The remaining members of TYPE O NEGATIVE made the heart-wrenching decision to disband rather than replace their irreplaceable frontman. As drummer Johnny Kelly poignantly expressed, “Even if there is somebody who could take his place it wouldn’t matter. We don’t have any interest in continuing. It’s impossible – it hasn’t even come up in any kind of discussion. When Peter died, Type O Negative died with him.”

As a lasting tribute, an oak tree was planted in Prospect Park on November 21, 2011, to honor the memory of Peter Steele.

A Legacy That Endures

Peter‘s untimely, and unexpected death left a void in the world of music that has yet to be filled. His impact on gothic metal and heavy metal as a whole is absolutely undeniable. His music continues to be discovered and resonate with new generations of fans, and TYPE O NEGATIVE‘s albums remain essential listening for those seeking a darker, more introspective sound.

The profound impact of Steele‘s music and artistry is evident in the countless tributes paid by fellow musicians. From heavy metal to rock, artists across multiple genres have honored his memory through their work. Bands such as NECROPHAGIA, VOYAGER, and LACUNA COIL dedicated entire songs to Steele, while others like fellow New York hardcore act BIOHAZARD and even Finland’s own SWALLOW THE SUN have expressed their reverence through album dedications.

Cover versions of TYPE O NEGATIVE classics, including “I Don’t Wanna Be Me” and “Love You to Death,” by artists like MERIDIAN DAWN, STARSET, PALLBEARER and TRIVIUM, serve as powerful testaments to Steele‘s enduring influence. Even beyond the metal realm, performers like pop artist Jessie Frye have recognized Steele‘s impact, paying tribute to his music. These heartfelt expressions showcase only the tip of the iceberg of the deep respect and massive admiration the music world holds for the late frontman.

It may be cliché to say, but the memory of Peter Steele lives on through his music, which to this very day continues to provide solace and inspiration to countless fans around the world. Even Peter‘s fellow TYPE O NEGATIVE bandmates are still in awe of the recognition and admiration the group gets all these years later.

Johnny Kelly previously said to us on an edition of The Loaded Radio Podcast, “It blows my mind that it’s 2023 and we’re still here talking about TYPE O NEGATIVE. It’s like we haven’t been this big since “Bloody Kisses” came out!” to which guitarist Kenny Hickey agreed, saying “It really does seem that way.”
